co-catalyst.source: By the in situ hydrothermal method, BiVO 4 / Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 samples with different mole ratios (20 mol, 10 mol, and 5 mol ) of Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 were prepared for comparison.
co-catalyst.context: All the chemical reagents were of analytical grade and purchased from Aladdin Industrial Corporation and used without further purification.Deionized water was used throughout the work. The molten salt synthesis method was used to prepare Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 , where Bi 2 O 3 and TiO 2 (anatase) were used as raw materials.Since mole ratio of Bi 2 O 3 to TiO 2 is 2:3 in Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 , Bi 2 O 3 and TiO 2 were mixed by the stoichiometric amounts.Then, NaCl, KCl and Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 were mixed at a mole ratio of 60:60:1 and continuously grinded for over 30 min with an agate mortar and pestle.The resulting mixture was then calcined at 800 C for 2 h in Muffle furnace.The mixed NaCl and KCl can be totally melted at 800 C according to the eutectic point, which is the vital steps for the generation of Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 .The resulting white product was washed with deionized water until the ion concentration gets close to zero, followed by overnight drying in an electric oven at 333 K. BiVO 4 nanomaterial was prepared by a simple in situ hydrothermal method.First, 1 mmol bismuth nitrate pentahydrate (Bi(NO 3 ) 3 5H 2 O) and 0.1 g sodium dodecyl benzene sulfonate (SDBS) were separately dissolved in 6 mL and 5 mL of 2 M nitric acid solution under vigorous stirring to obtain the transparency liquid A. 1 mmol NH 4 VO 3 was dissolved in 6 mL of 2 M nitric acid to obtained the solution B. Then, the solution B was poured quickly into the solution A. A clear orange solution was formed after vigorous stirring, and then to which different molar ratios of Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 was added.In order to adjust the acid concentration to 1 M, the prepared solution was diluted by a certain amount of de-ionized water.The final resulting 35 mL solution was transferred into a 50 ml Teflon-lined autoclave and maintained at 423 K for 12 h, followed by naturally cooling to room temperature.The final product was gathered by centrifugation, rinsed thoroughly with deionized water, followed by desiccation at 60 C in air overnight for further characterization.By the in situ hydrothermal method, BiVO 4 / Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 samples with different mole ratios (20 mol, 10 mol, and 5 mol ) of Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 were prepared for comparison.In addition, the nude BiVO 4 as a reference sample was prepared also by the hydrothermal method similar to the above procedure but no adding Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 .For simplicity, Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 will be abbreviated as BTO and BiVO 4 done as BVO hereinafter. Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer (XRD) with Cu K1 radiation ( 1.5406A) was used to analyze the crystalline phases of the samples.Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were taken on a field emission scanning electron microscope (Nova Nano SEM 230) was used to observe the morphology.The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained via a JEOL model JEM 2010 EX instrument at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV.The chemical compositions of the samples were analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra by a VG ESCALAB 250 XPS System with a monochromatized Al K X-ray source (15 kV, 200 W, 500 m, pass energy 20 eV).All binding energies (BEs) of the spectra were corrected to the C 1s peak at 284.8 eV of the surficial deposited carbon.UV-vis diffuse reflection spectra (DRS) of the samples were performed with a Cary-500 spectrophotometer, and barium sulfate was used as the reflectance standard.Photoluminescence spectra (PL) were detected at room temperature on a fluorescence spectrophotometer (FLS 980, excitation wavelength 280 nm).In situ CO 2 -adsorbed FT-IR experiments were implemented on a Nicolet 670 FT-IR spectrometer at a resolution of 4 cm -1 and 32 scans.The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface area was calculated from the N 2 adsorption isothermal that was determined by a Quantachrome Autosorb IQ-C nitrogen adsorption apparatus.The photoelectrochemical measurements were carried on a conventional three-electrode electrochemical cell consisting of a working electrode (sample), counter electrode (platinum foil) and reference electrode (Ag/AgCl electrode (3.0 M KCl)).The photocurrent with light/dark short-circuit response was recorded by a BAS Epsilon workstation.Sodium sulfate electrolyte solution (0.2 M) was used as the electrolyte solution.The UV-vis irradiation source was a 300 W Xe lamp.The work functions of BiVO 4 and Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 were determined by Kelvin probe system (SKP5050, KPTechnology Ltd.) with a single-point measurement.Also, the contact potential difference (CPD) between the sample and the tip (gold, 5.1 eV) was measured in the dark.The work function of the tip was initially corrected using a gold disk.The work function of the sample was calculated by the following formula: WF of sample WF of tip CPD The photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 with H 2 O vapor was carried out in a 270 mL Schlenk flask reactor under atmospheric pressure at ambient temperature (298 K).The reactor was equipped with two venting valves and a sampling port sealed with a silicone rubber septum.The light source, a 300 W commercial Xe lamp with a focus intensity of 0.2 W cm -2 (300D, Perfectlight, China), was vertically placed outside the reactor.10 mg photocatalyst powder was dispersed in the bottom of reactor.Subsequently, the reactor was evacuated by a mechanical pump and filled with pure CO 2 gas at atmospheric pressure.This evacuation-filling operation was repeated several times to remove residual air. 10 L of pure water was injected into the reactor from the silicone rubber septum by a microsyringe and then the photosource was turned on.After 3 h irradiation, 0.5 mL reaction gas was sampled from the reactor and analyzed by a gas chromatograph (GC-7890B, Agilent) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID), and a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a chromatographic column (TDX-01).which could be seen clearly from the XRD peaks at 2 28 31(Fig.1b).It's worth noting that a new diffraction peak appears at 2 11.9withincreasing BTO content (Fig. 1b).These show that both BiVO 4 and Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 keep their respective crystal phase in their composite, and there is interaction occurring at the interface between them.

light source.source: The photocatalytic CO 2 reduction with H 2 O on the as-prepared photocatalysts was investigated under a 300 W Xe lamp irradiation without using any sacrificial reagent, as shown in Fig. 2.
light source.context: The photocatalytic CO 2 reduction with H 2 O on the as-prepared photocatalysts was investigated under a 300 W Xe lamp irradiation without using any sacrificial reagent, as shown in Fig. 2. Two carboncontaining products CO and CH 3 OH were detected as main products for the reactions 42,43.However, evolution rates of products were different for BiVO S3), and its amount is close to the stoichiometric value estimated from the practical evolution amount of CO and CH 3 OH and reaction equations (CO 2 CO 1/2O 2 , and CO 2 2H 2 O CH 3 OH 3/2O 2 ).In addition, the stability test, as showed in Fig. 2b, indicates that the BiVO 4 /10 Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 sample maintains stable activity after 4 cycles in total 12 h.And in the cycle process, the phase structure of the photocatalyst has not noticeable change before and after the cycle reaction (Figure S4).The photocatalytic activity level of BiVO 4 /10 Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 is higher than that of many photocatalyst for the reduction of CO 2 with H 2 O to CH 3 OH and/or CO in the comparable conditions 42,44,2.3c andd).In addition, the BiVO 4 particles are uniformly distributed without significant agglomeration on the surface of Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 and the size of BiVO 4 is obviously smaller than that in the nude state.Figure S6 shows the UV-vis diffuse reflection spectra of BiVO 4 , BiVO 4 /10 Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 and Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 .The nude BiVO 4 shows a bandedge absorption at ca. 545 nm, corresponding to a band gap energy of 2.45 eV (Figure S6a).Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 exhibits an obvious band-edge absorption with wavelength at ca. 405 nm, corresponding to a band gap energy of 3.19 eV (Figure S6a), which has no difference with that reported for Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 in the literature 38.The band-edge absorption of BiVO 4 /10 Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 slightly shifts towards shorter wavelengths with increasing content of Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 .The valence band potentials of BiVO 4 and Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 , which were estimated by the valence band spectrum method 30,45 are 1.65 and 1.30 eV (vs.NHE), respectively (Figure S6b).Combined with the band gaps, we could estimate that the conduction band potentials of BiVO 4 and Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 are -0.80V and -1.89 V, respectively.The conduction band potential of BiVO 4 is more negative than the reported (-0.45 -0.2 V) 30,40.On this account, the conduction band positions of BiVO 4 was verified further by the Mott-Schottky (MS) plot method (Figure S7) to be -0.78V vs NHE), which is almost identical with that estimated by valence band spectrum.The difference of conduction band potentials of BiVO 4 from the some literature values could result from the changes in structure factors, including the morphology, size, crystal and surface defect, etc. induced by different preparation method. Kelvin probe technology with single-point measurements over 600 points was applied to determine work functions of the two semiconductor materials, as shown in Fig. 6.Since CPD for Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 is higher than that for BiVO 4 , therefore the work function (WF) of Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 (5.78eV) is higher than that of BiVO 4 (5.5 eV).Further combined with electron affinity data (EA) of Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 (5.868The charge transfer direction in the BiVO 4 /Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 sample was confirmed by a photoinduced redox probe reactions, Pt 4 e - Pt, and Mn 2 h OH - MnO x 7.shows some weak IR bands in the range of 1000 -1600 cm -1 on the BiVO 4 /10 Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 , which belongs to different adsorption states of CO 2 32,46.However, after light irradiation, besides the surface adsorption species CO 2 observed before illumination, other some bicarbonate species were found, such as the formate (HCOO -) species at 1340 cm -1 , monodentate carbonate at 1539 cm -1 , bidentate carbonate at 1238 cm -1 and 1160 cm -1 , and methoxy at 1029 and 1078 cm -1 47,48.This suggests that CO 2 undergoes these complex intermediate states and is finally reduced to CH 3 OH and CO on the photocatalyst. The possible reduction mechanism of CO 2 over the BiVO 4 /Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 heterojunction composites is proposed in Fig. 11, based on the above results and the previous reports 49,50.Products CO and CH 3 OH may be produced from two parallel photocatalytic routes.First, CO 2 molecule is adsorbed on the surface of BiVO H into one carboxyl radical and then further reduced by another photogenerated electron and H to CO and H 2 O.The whole process can be expressed as CO 2 H 2 O CO 1/2O 2 H 2 O (where H 2 O takes part in the reaction, but it was eventually released).This mechanism is similar to that on BiOBr we suggested previously 2.(ii) It is reduced by the two photogenerated electron and 2H into -CH 2 O 2 species, and then undergoes the subsequent series processes, including the hole-oxidizing lattice oxygen, the oxygen vacancy despoiling O 2-in H 2 O, the reaction with photogenerated electrons and H ions, etc., finally to CH 3 OH step by step.The whole process can be expressed with chemical equation CO 2 2H 2 O CH 3 OH 3/2O 2 .Because the two routes involve similar intermediate species, in theory there should be near product selectivity.But in fact, selectivity of CH 3 OH is slightly higher than that of CO, which can be related with the dosage of reactant H 2 O (this result will be published in separated paper).

reaction medium.source: BiVO4 /Bi4Ti3O12 heterojunction enabling efficient photocatalytic reduction of CO2 with H2O to CH3OH and CO
reaction medium.context: BiVO4 /Bi4Ti3O12 heterojunction enabling efficient photocatalytic reduction of CO2 with H2O to CH3OH and CO

reaction medium.source: The novel composite photocatalyst has excellent photocatalytic ability to reduce CO 2 with H 2 O into CH 3 OH and CO.
reaction medium.context: Construction of composite semiconductors is an effective solution to elevate the efficiency of photocatalysis by prolonging lifetime of photogenerated hole and electrons.Herein, a heterojunction structure composite BiVO 4 / Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 was synthesized via a facile in situ hydrothermal condition.The novel composite photocatalyst has excellent photocatalytic ability to reduce CO 2 with H 2 O into CH 3 OH and CO.The BiVO 4 /10 Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 sample shows the highest yields of CH 3 OH and CO up to 16.6 and 13.29 mol g -1 h -1 , which was 12.39 and 5.68 times higher than that of pure BiVO 4 , and 9.88 and 2.80 times higher than that of pure Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 , respectively.Such a high activity is attributed to the type II heterojunction structure which significantly enhances separation of photogenerated carriers and promotes collaboration between the water oxidation on the Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 and the CO 2 reduction on BiVO 4 .The photocatalytic reaction mechanism of CO 2 on the composite was proposed according to experiment results.

reaction medium.source: The photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 with H 2 O vapor was carried out in a 270 mL Schlenk flask reactor under atmospheric pressure at ambient temperature (298 K).
reaction medium.context: All the chemical reagents were of analytical grade and purchased from Aladdin Industrial Corporation and used without further purification.Deionized water was used throughout the work. The molten salt synthesis method was used to prepare Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 , where Bi 2 O 3 and TiO 2 (anatase) were used as raw materials.Since mole ratio of Bi 2 O 3 to TiO 2 is 2:3 in Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 , Bi 2 O 3 and TiO 2 were mixed by the stoichiometric amounts.Then, NaCl, KCl and Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 were mixed at a mole ratio of 60:60:1 and continuously grinded for over 30 min with an agate mortar and pestle.The resulting mixture was then calcined at 800 C for 2 h in Muffle furnace.The mixed NaCl and KCl can be totally melted at 800 C according to the eutectic point, which is the vital steps for the generation of Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 .The resulting white product was washed with deionized water until the ion concentration gets close to zero, followed by overnight drying in an electric oven at 333 K. BiVO 4 nanomaterial was prepared by a simple in situ hydrothermal method.First, 1 mmol bismuth nitrate pentahydrate (Bi(NO 3 ) 3 5H 2 O) and 0.1 g sodium dodecyl benzene sulfonate (SDBS) were separately dissolved in 6 mL and 5 mL of 2 M nitric acid solution under vigorous stirring to obtain the transparency liquid A. 1 mmol NH 4 VO 3 was dissolved in 6 mL of 2 M nitric acid to obtained the solution B. Then, the solution B was poured quickly into the solution A. A clear orange solution was formed after vigorous stirring, and then to which different molar ratios of Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 was added.In order to adjust the acid concentration to 1 M, the prepared solution was diluted by a certain amount of de-ionized water.The final resulting 35 mL solution was transferred into a 50 ml Teflon-lined autoclave and maintained at 423 K for 12 h, followed by naturally cooling to room temperature.The final product was gathered by centrifugation, rinsed thoroughly with deionized water, followed by desiccation at 60 C in air overnight for further characterization.By the in situ hydrothermal method, BiVO 4 / Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 samples with different mole ratios (20 mol, 10 mol, and 5 mol ) of Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 were prepared for comparison.In addition, the nude BiVO 4 as a reference sample was prepared also by the hydrothermal method similar to the above procedure but no adding Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 .For simplicity, Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 will be abbreviated as BTO and BiVO 4 done as BVO hereinafter. The possible reduction mechanism of CO 2 over the BiVO 4 /Bi 4 Ti 3 O 12 heterojunction composites is proposed in Fig. 11, based on the above results and the previous reports 49,50.Products CO and CH 3 OH may be produced from two parallel photocatalytic routes.First, CO 2 molecule is adsorbed on the surface of BiVO H into one carboxyl radical and then further reduced by another photogenerated electron and H to CO and H 2 O.The whole process can be expressed as CO 2 H 2 O CO 1/2O 2 H 2 O (where H 2 O takes part in the reaction, but it was eventually released).This mechanism is similar to that on BiOBr we suggested previously 2.(ii) It is reduced by the two photogenerated electron and 2H into -CH 2 O 2 species, and then undergoes the subsequent series processes, including the hole-oxidizing lattice oxygen, the oxygen vacancy despoiling O 2-in H 2 O, the reaction with photogenerated electrons and H ions, etc., finally to CH 3 OH step by step.The whole process can be expressed with chemical equation CO 2 2H 2 O CH 3 OH 3/2O 2 .Because the two routes involve similar intermediate species, in theory there should be near product selectivity.But in fact, selectivity of CH 3 OH is slightly higher than that of CO, which can be related with the dosage of reactant H 2 O (this result will be published in separated paper).
